title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to fuzzystring
text: outlines propose change fuzzystring. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to fuzzystring
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to fuzzystring
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to fuzzystring
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("PaulESantos/fuzzystring", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to fuzzystring
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use Air apply style, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to fuzzystring
text: Please note fuzzystring project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with fuzzystring
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty incredible ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with fuzzystring
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

Typically don’t look repo sufficient quantity issues accumulates, ’s burst intense activity focus efforts. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !

what: Join two tables based on fuzzy string matching — fuzzystring_join
title: Join two tables based on fuzzy string matching — fuzzystring_join
text: Uses stringdist::stringdist() compute distances data.table-based backend assemble final result. main user-facing entry point fuzzy joins strings.

title: Join two tables based on fuzzy string matching — fuzzystring_join
code: fuzzystring_join(   x,   y,   by = NULL,   max_dist = 2,   method = c("osa", "lv", "dl", "hamming", "lcs", "qgram", "cosine", "jaccard", "jw",     "soundex"),   mode = "inner",   ignore_case = FALSE,   distance_col = NULL,   ... )  fuzzystring_inner_join(x, y, by = NULL, distance_col = NULL, ...)  fuzzystring_left_join(x, y, by = NULL, distance_col = NULL, ...)  fuzzystring_right_join(x, y, by = NULL, distance_col = NULL, ...)  fuzzystring_full_join(x, y, by = NULL, distance_col = NULL, ...)  fuzzystring_semi_join(x, y, by = NULL, distance_col = NULL, ...)  fuzzystring_anti_join(x, y, by = NULL, distance_col = NULL, ...)

title: Join two tables based on fuzzy string matching — fuzzystring_join
text: x data.frame data.table. y data.frame data.table. Columns join two tables. can supply character vector common names (e.g. c("name") ), named vector mapping x y (e.g. c(name = "approx_name")). max_dist Maximum distance use joining. Smaller values stricter. method Method computing string distance, see ?stringdist::stringdist stringdist package vignettes. mode One "inner", "left", "right", "full", "semi", "anti". ignore_case Logical; TRUE, comparisons case-insensitive. distance_col NULL, adds column name containing computed distance matched pair (NA unmatched rows outer joins). ... Additional arguments passed stringdist.

title: Join two tables based on fuzzy string matching — fuzzystring_join
text: joined table (container type x). See fuzzystring_join_backend details output structure.

title: Join two tables based on fuzzy string matching — fuzzystring_join
text: method = "soundex", max_dist automatically set 0.5, since Soundex distance 0 (match) 1 (match). Levenshtein-like methods ("osa", "lv", "dl"), fast prefilter applied: abs(nchar(v1) - nchar(v2)) > max_dist, pair match, distance computed pair.

title: Join two tables based on fuzzy string matching — fuzzystring_join
code: if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   d <- data.table::data.table(approximate_name = c("Idea", "Premiom"))   # Match diamonds$cut to d$approximate_name   res <- fuzzystring_inner_join(ggplot2::diamonds, d,     by = c(cut = "approximate_name"),     max_dist = 1   )   head(res) } #>    carat     cut color clarity depth table price     x     y     z #>    <num>   <ord> <ord>   <ord> <num> <num> <int> <num> <num> <num> #> 1:  0.23   Ideal     E     SI2  61.5    55   326  3.95  3.98  2.43 #> 2:  0.21 Premium     E     SI1  59.8    61   326  3.89  3.84  2.31 #> 3:  0.29 Premium     I     VS2  62.4    58   334  4.20  4.23  2.63 #> 4:  0.23   Ideal     J     VS1  62.8    56   340  3.93  3.90  2.46 #> 5:  0.22 Premium     F     SI1  60.4    61   342  3.88  3.84  2.33 #> 6:  0.31   Ideal     J     SI2  62.2    54   344  4.35  4.37  2.71 #>    approximate_name #>              <char> #> 1:             Idea #> 2:          Premiom #> 3:          Premiom #> 4:             Idea #> 5:          Premiom #> 6:             Idea

what: Fuzzy join backend using data.table + C++ row binding — fuzzystring_join_backend
title: Fuzzy join backend using data.table + C++ row binding — fuzzystring_join_backend
text: Low-level engine used fuzzystring_join C++-optimized fuzzy join helpers. builds match index R/data.table assembles result using compiled C++ binder speed.

title: Fuzzy join backend using data.table + C++ row binding — fuzzystring_join_backend
code: fuzzystring_join_backend(   x,   y,   by = NULL,   match_fun = NULL,   multi_by = NULL,   multi_match_fun = NULL,   index_match_fun = NULL,   mode = "inner",   ... )

title: Fuzzy join backend using data.table + C++ row binding — fuzzystring_join_backend
text: x data.frame data.table. y data.frame data.table. Columns join two tables. See fuzzystring_join. match_fun function used match values. must return logical vector (data.frame/data.table whose first column logical) indicating pairs match. multi-column joins, may pass list functions (one per column). multi_by character vector column names used multi-column matching multi_match_fun supplied. multi_match_fun function receives matrices unique values x y (rows correspond unique combinations multi_by). must return logical vector (data.frame/data.table whose first column logical) indicating rows match. index_match_fun function receives joined columns x y returns table integer columns x y (1-based row indices). mode One "inner", "left", "right", "full", "semi", "anti". ... Additional arguments passed matching function(s).

title: Fuzzy join backend using data.table + C++ row binding — fuzzystring_join_backend
text: joined table (container type x). See fuzzystring_join.

title: Fuzzy join backend using data.table + C++ row binding — fuzzystring_join_backend
text: function works like fuzzystring_join, replaces R-based row binding C++ implementation. provides better performance, especially large joins many matches. intended backend compute distances ; use fuzzystring_join string-distance based matching. C++ implementation handles: Efficient subsetting row indices Proper handling NA values outer joins Type-safe column operations common R types Preservation factor levels attributes Column name conflicts .x/.y suffixes

A corpus of common misspellings, for examples and practice — misspellings

title: A corpus of common misspellings, for examples and practice — misspellings
text: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Lists_of_common_misspellings/For_machines

title: A corpus of common misspellings, for examples and practice — misspellings
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(rvest) library(readr) library(dplyr) library(stringr) library(tidyr)  u <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Lists_of_common_misspellings/For_machines" h <- read_html(u)  misspellings <- h %>%   html_nodes("pre") %>%   html_text() %>%   readr::read_delim(col_names = c("misspelling", "correct"), delim = ">",                     skip = 1) %>%   mutate(misspelling = str_sub(misspelling, 1, -2)) %>%   unnest(correct = str_split(correct, ", ")) %>%   filter(Encoding(correct) != "UTF-8") } # }
